name: smilax lasioneura
description:
Common Carrion Flower is a climbing vine with tendrils that
can grow up to 7 feet in ideal conditions, but most plants are smaller in size,
especially in the northern part of its range. The vine has blue-black berries
that are eaten by game birds and song birds, plus a number of mammals including
black bear and racoon. As the name suggests, the flower emits a foul odor which
varies in strength by ecotype. As you might guess, this species is primarily
pollinated by flies attracted by the scent, but it also attracts beetles and
small bees. 
The genus name “Smilax” is Greek for “clasping” and
originates from the Greek myth of Crocus and the nymph, named Smilax. Though
this myth is told in a number of different ways, it always centers around the
tragic love story of a mortal man who is turned into a flower (Crocus or
Saffron), and a woodland nymph who is transformed into a brambly vine (Smilax).
Many plants in the Smilax genus have a bad reputation for growing
as woody, thorny thickets, but this species is neither woody or thorny. The
non-woody species in the Smilax genus including Carrion Flowers and Smooth
Greenbrair have been previously separated into the Nemexia genus,
but is not currently considered an accepted genus
by most authorities in plant taxonomy. Other names for this plant include Nemexia
lasioneura, Smilax herbacea var. lasioneura, Blue Ridge Carrion Flower, Hairy
Carrion Flower, and Hairy-Nerved Carrion Flower.
features: Deer Resistant (Our experiences here in the Upper Midwest may vary in other regions; deer can respond differently to local conditions or seasonal variations.)
